title: City watchdog left red-faced after pension blunder it would not tolerate from others
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now City watchdog left red-faced after pension blunder it would not tolerate from others Martin Wheatley, the chief executive, scooped a performance-related bonus of £92,000 for the year to April this year Simon Dawson/ Getty Images Google+ 1 of 1 Martin Wheatley, the chief executive, scooped a performance-related bonus of £92,000 for the year to April this year Simon Dawson/ Getty Images Patrick Hosking Financial Editor Published at 12:01AM, July 3 2015 
It’s a mistake no financial regulator could possibly tolerate. A blue-chip employer hands out pay rises to more than a thousand staff, but omits to raise their pension contributions by the right amount at the same time. 
The stock market, meanwhile, goes up and by the time the error is discovered, the employees have lost out. 
The blundering employer in this case, however, was the Financial Conduct Authority, the chief regulator, best known for handing out nine-digit fines for failings at City firms. It confessed to the error in a two-line sentence buried on page 122 of its annual report Subscribe now
